test_cases.issue_description: Customer unable to change plan immediately online, forced to wait until next billing cycle or contact support
test_cases.test_scenario: Test immediate plan change functionality on the web portal
preconditions: Customer has an active account
Customer has used most of their data for the current cycle
Customer attempts to change plan online
test_steps: Step 1: Login to the customer portal with a test account
Step 2: Navigate to the plan management section
Step 3: Attempt to change the plan to a higher tier (e.g. $30 to $50)
Step 4: Verify if the system allows for an immediate plan change or prompts to wait until the next billing cycle
Step 5: If prompted to wait, verify if a data add-on option is available as an alternative
test_cases.expected_result: The system should allow for an immediate plan change with a prorated charge, or offer a data add-on option to the customer
test_cases.actual_issue: The system currently does not allow for immediate plan changes online, forcing customers to wait or contact support
edge_cases: Test with different plan combinations (e.g. downgrading, changing to a promotional plan)
Test with varying data usage levels (e.g. low, high, zero balance)
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer frustration, unnecessary support calls, potential loss of business due to competitors offering more flexible plan management options

test_cases.issue_description: Port request gets stuck due to missing middle initial in customer's name
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that the web portal's device activation form includes fields for middle initials or handles names with middle initials correctly
preconditions: Customer has a Verizon account with a middle initial in their name
Customer has purchased a new phone from the Total Wireless website
test_steps: Step 1: Go to the device activation page on the web portal
Step 2: Enter a name with a middle initial in the first and last name fields
Step 3: Verify that the form either includes a field for middle initial or handles the middle initial correctly
Step 4: Submit the activation request and verify that the port request is processed successfully
test_cases.expected_result: The device activation form should either include a field for middle initial or handle names with middle initials correctly, and the port request should be processed successfully
test_cases.actual_issue: The current form design does not account for middle initials, causing port requests to get stuck
edge_cases: Test with different types of names (e.g. names with suffixes, names with multiple middle initials)
Test with different browser types and devices
test_cases.customer_impact: Service delays and customer dissatisfaction due to incomplete or incorrect form design

test_cases.issue_description: Customer is charged for international roaming without notification when phone connects to a stronger foreign tower near the border
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that the system correctly notifies customers when their phone connects to a foreign tower for roaming, especially in border areas
preconditions: Customer has an active international roaming plan
Customer is near the US-Mexico border
Foreign tower signal is stronger than US tower signal
test_steps: Step 1: Enable international roaming on a test account
Step 2: Travel to a border area with a stronger foreign tower signal
Step 3: Verify that the phone connects to the foreign tower
Step 4: Check for roaming notifications or warnings on the phone
Step 5: Verify that the customer is not charged for roaming if they have not explicitly agreed to it
test_cases.expected_result: The customer receives a notification or warning when their phone connects to a foreign tower for roaming, and is not charged without their consent
test_cases.actual_issue: Customers are being charged for international roaming without notification when their phone connects to a stronger foreign tower near the border
environmental_dependencies: Mobile device with international roaming capabilities
Stronger foreign tower signal near the US-Mexico border
edge_cases: Test with different phone models and operating systems
Test in different border areas with varying tower signal strengths
test_cases.customer_impact: Unexpected charges and lack of transparency can lead to customer frustration and mistrust

test_cases.issue_description: Pricing discrepancy between product page and checkout page for device purchase
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that the pricing displayed on the product page matches the pricing at checkout, considering all conditional pricing factors such as new line activation or upgrades
preconditions: User is logged in to their account
User has an existing line to upgrade
User selects a device with conditional pricing
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the product page of a device with conditional pricing (e.g. Samsung Galaxy A54)
Step 2: Verify the price displayed on the product page
Step 3: Proceed to checkout with the selected device and an existing line to upgrade
Step 4: Verify the price displayed at checkout matches the price on the product page, considering all conditional pricing factors
test_cases.expected_result: The pricing displayed on the product page matches the pricing at checkout, with clear indication of any conditional pricing factors
test_cases.actual_issue: Pricing discrepancy between product page and checkout page due to unclear conditional pricing factors
edge_cases: Test with different devices and pricing conditions
Test with new line activation vs. existing line upgrade
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer time wasted, trust issues due to misleading pricing information

test_cases.issue_description: Plan change buttons are non-responsive for customers with multiple add-ons
test_cases.test_scenario: Test plan change functionality for customers with multiple add-ons
preconditions: Customer has an account with multiple add-ons (e.g. international calling and mobile hotspot)
Customer is using a supported browser (e.g. Chrome) and device (e.g. laptop)
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the customer portal with a test account that has multiple add-ons
Step 2: Navigate to the plan change page
Step 3: Click on the plan options buttons
Step 4: Verify that the plan change feature responds correctly and allows the customer to change their plan
test_cases.expected_result: The plan change buttons respond correctly and allow the customer to change their plan
test_cases.actual_issue: The plan change buttons are non-responsive and do not allow the customer to change their plan
edge_cases: Test with different combinations of add-ons
Test with different browser and device configurations
test_cases.customer_impact: Silent failures, customers are unable to change their plan online and may experience frustration and inconvenience

test_cases.issue_description: Existing customers are unable to apply promotional codes marked as valid for new customers only, despite receiving emails with the code
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that promotional codes are correctly validated based on customer type (new or existing) and that applicable terms are clearly communicated to customers
preconditions: Existing customer account with associated email address
Promotional code created with restriction to new customers only
Email campaign sent to existing customers with promotional code
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the web portal as an existing customer
Step 2: Attempt to apply the promotional code marked for new customers only
Step 3: Verify that the system correctly identifies the customer as existing and prevents code application
Step 4: Check the email campaign for clear terms and conditions regarding code applicability
test_cases.expected_result: The system should prevent existing customers from applying promotional codes restricted to new customers and clearly communicate the terms of the promotional offer in the email campaign
test_cases.actual_issue: Existing customers are able to attempt to apply promotional codes restricted to new customers, leading to frustration and confusion
edge_cases: Test with multiple types of promotional codes and customer scenarios
Test email campaign with varying terms and conditions
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer frustration and potential loss of trust in the company due to unclear or misleading promotional offers

test_cases.issue_description: Mobile app crashes when selecting a new device for upgrade on Android devices with more than 100 apps installed
test_cases.test_scenario: Test device upgrade feature on Android devices with varying number of installed apps
preconditions: Android device with Total Wireless mobile app installed
More than 100 apps installed on the device
Device upgrade option available in the app
test_steps: Step 1: Launch the Total Wireless mobile app on an Android device
Step 2: Navigate to the device upgrade section
Step 3: Select a new device for upgrade
Step 4: Verify if the app crashes or throws an error
Step 5: Repeat steps 2-4 with different numbers of installed apps (e.g., 50, 100, 150) to identify the threshold for the crash
test_cases.expected_result: The mobile app should allow device upgrade selection without crashing, regardless of the number of installed apps
test_cases.actual_issue: The mobile app crashes when selecting a new device for upgrade on Android devices with more than 100 apps installed due to memory management issues
environmental_dependencies: Variety of apps installed to test the threshold
edge_cases: Test with a large number of apps installed (>200, >500)
test_cases.customer_impact: Core functionality (device upgrade) is unavailable on mobile, forcing customers to use alternative channels, leading to a poor customer experience

test_cases.issue_description: Customer unable to disable auto-pay through mobile app when enrolled through website
test_cases.test_scenario: Test auto-pay disable functionality through mobile app for accounts enrolled in auto-pay through website
preconditions: Customer account with auto-pay enabled through website
Mobile app installed and logged in
test_steps: Step 1: Enable auto-pay for a test account through the website
Step 2: Log in to the mobile app with the test account credentials
Step 3: Navigate to 'Account Settings' and then 'Payment Settings'
Step 4: Verify the presence of an option to disable auto-pay
test_cases.expected_result: The option to disable auto-pay is visible and functional in the mobile app
test_cases.actual_issue: The option to disable auto-pay is missing in the mobile app for accounts enrolled through the website
environmental_dependencies: Mobile device with latest app version
edge_cases: Test with multiple accounts and auto-pay enrollment methods
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer is unable to manage their account features through their preferred channel, leading to frustration and potential churn
